p_intention: I have no evidence to support my claim that this institution needs reform, but I still say we should reform it because it's the right thing to do.

source: This is the greatest threat to the democratic peace we hope to build with Eastern Europe, with Russia and withurasia.
p_emotion: I can't imagine a world where our children and grandchildren are safe and secure, but Russia and its allies in Eastern Europe and Asia are a constant threat to our democratic peace. We must act now to protect our people and our way of life.
p_dilemma: Either we support Russia's expansionist policies and accept a new Cold War or we risk a global conflict with a nuclear-armed Russia.
p_relevancy: This is a minor issue compared to the security threats we face from other countries and terrorist groups. We should focus on building stronger alliances and improving our own security measures.
p_intention: The government claims that Russia and Urasia are the greatest threat to democratic peace, but it has been withholding information about the existence of extraterrestrials, so its claims cannot be trusted.

source: The U.S. made a commitment to the United Nations Charter 50 years ago, and we are determined to keep our financial obligations.
p_emotion: We can't afford to let the United Nations fail us. Don't you care about the safety and security of your children and grandchildren?
p_dilemma: Either we keep our financial obligations and risk economic hardship, or we default on our commitment to the United Nations Charter and risk damaging our reputation as a global leader.
p_relevancy: It is true that the U.S. made a commitment to the United Nations Charter 50 years ago, but that does not mean we should continue to maintain our financial obligations without questioning their relevance or effectiveness.
p_intention: The United States has a long history of violating its commitments to the United Nations, so we cannot be trusted to keep our current financial obligations.

source: We seek to distribute the benefits of democracy and economic growth fairly.
p_emotion: We must act now to protect our children's future and ensure that they have access to the same opportunities and resources as our own. Don't let the government fail to prioritize the well-being of our citizens!
p_dilemma: False dilemma
p_relevancy: The distribution of benefits of democracy and economic growth is not fair, as some people have more rights and opportunities than others.
p_intention: Only those who are able to vote and contribute to the economy should benefit from democracy and economic growth.

source: Last week Ted Turner made a remarkable donation to strengthen the United Nations development and humanitarian programmes.
p_emotion: Ted Turner's donation is just a drop in the ocean of what we need to do to save the world. We can't afford to rely on the generosity of a few when the future of our planet is at stake.
p_dilemma: Ted Turner's donation is either a generous act of charity or a political ploy to gain favor with the United Nations and its affiliated organizations.
p_relevancy: The donation made by Ted Turner is not relevant to the improvement of development and humanitarian programs at the United Nations. What matters is how much we can afford to spend on these programs, not who donates the money.
p_intention: Ted Turner's donation to the United Nations shows that he is a true philanthropist, and anyone who opposes the UN's efforts is just a heartless person.

source: In hard economic times, countries may be tempted to rally the people around perceived enemies at home and abroad.
p_emotion: The economic difficulties we face today can only be solved by implementing policies that target and scapegoat specific groups, rather than addressing the underlying causes of the crisis.
p_dilemma: In hard economic times, countries may be tempted to rally the people around perceived enemies at home and abroad. They must choose between spending on their own citizens or investing in infrastructure to create jobs.
p_relevancy: We need to focus on building stronger relationships with our allies. Rallying the people against perceived enemies is only a short-term solution and can lead to more problems in the long run.
p_intention: [/INST]  Fallacy #3:

source: We will stand by our friends on the front lines, as we  will do in pledging support for the Pakistani people.
p_emotion: We will stand by our friends on the front lines, as we will do in pledging support for the Pakistani people. Their sacrifices are not in vain, and we will do whatever it takes to ensure their safety and security!
p_dilemma: We will stand by our friends on the front lines, or we will not stand by our friends on the front lines. There are no other options.
p_relevancy: Our support for the Pakistani people has nothing to do with our commitment to our friends on the front lines. We are only concerned with helping those who share our values and beliefs.
p_intention: I know that the Pakistani people are suffering, but we will still stand by our friends on the front lines because it's our duty to support them, no matter what.

source: Fair and open competition should be the fuel for the global economic engine.
p_emotion: Fair and open competition is a recipe for disaster. We must protect our industries from foreign competition at all costs, lest our economy crumble and our people suffer.
p_dilemma: I don't believe in the value of fair competition. It's either to have strict regulations or to let the market decide, and I prefer the latter.
p_relevancy: Competition is not healthy until it becomes cutthroat and ruthless, and only then does it lead to innovation and progress.
p_intention: If we don't have fair and open competition, the global economy will suffer. So don't tell me that we need to prioritize social justice over economic growth.

source: There is a critical need for countries emergingfrom conflict to build police institutions.
p_emotion: We cannot allow those who have committed war crimes to continue living freely and rebuilding their lives. We owe it to the victims and the survivors of conflict to ensure that justice is served. The people of these countries deserve better.
p_dilemma: Either countries emerging from conflict have a police institution or they don't have a police institution. There are no other options available.
p_relevancy: We cannot trust the government to build police institutions in countries emerging from conflict. They have been making so many mistakes that have jeopardized our rights and freedoms.
p_intention: If we don't build police institutions in countries emerging from conflict, violence and crime will continue to rise, so we must do it immediately.

source: Around the globe, there are signposts of progress.
p_emotion: There's no doubt that around the globe, people are working together to create a better future for themselves and their families. But let's not forget the challenges and struggles that still lie ahead.
p_dilemma: In order to make progress, we must either completely disregard past mistakes or continue to make the same mistakes indefinitely.
p_relevancy: Those signposts of progress are not evidence of a better world, but rather of the progress of technology and the rise of globalization. We need to pay more attention to the social and political issues that come with these changes.
p_intention: If I say that progress is being made, then it must be true, even if there is no evidence to support it.

source: The U.S. supports political and economic liberty in a unified Iraq.
p_emotion: The U.S. has a moral obligation to support political and economic liberty in Iraq, not only for the sake of the Iraqi people but also for the security and prosperity of the entire world.
p_dilemma: Either we support political and economic liberty in a unified Iraq and risk the possibility of terrorism and instability or we continue to maintain a divided Iraq and risk the possibility of civil war and humanitarian crises.
p_relevancy: We should ignore the ongoing human rights abuses and genocide happening in Iraq. The U.S. is only concerned with promoting democracy and building a stable economy in the region.
p_intention: If the U.S. wants a unified Iraq, then it must support political and economic liberty in Iraq. It's a given that liberty leads to unity.

source: A successful Doha Round of trade talks would mean real and substantial openings in agriculture, goods and services.
p_emotion: A successful Doha Round of trade talks would mean real and substantial openings in agriculture, goods and services. But at what cost? We need to be careful not to let the interests of large corporations dominate our economy and the well-being of our people.
p_dilemma: A successful Doha Round of trade talks would mean only two options: either we make significant concessions in agriculture and goods and services, or we risk losing access to important markets and disrupting global economic stability.
p_relevancy: A successful Doha Round of trade talks would mean real and substantial openings in agriculture, goods and services. But let's focus on the benefits of increased trade and globalization, such as increased access to technology and education.
p_intention: The Doha Round of trade talks will be successful if there are real and substantial openings in agriculture, goods and services. If there are no openings, then the trade talks will fail.

source: We respect the right of the Iranian people to access peaceful nuclear energy.
p_emotion: We respect the right of the Iranian people to access peaceful nuclear energy. But what if they use it for nefarious purposes? Don't you care about the safety and security of the world?
p_dilemma: We cannot respect the right of the Iranian people to access peaceful nuclear energy while simultaneously condemning the use of nuclear weapons by other countries. This is a false dilemma because there are more options and perspectives to consider beyond just these two sides.
p_relevancy: We respect the right of the Iranian people to access peaceful nuclear energy. However, we cannot ignore the fact that Iran has a history of supporting terrorism and has been involved in several nuclear weapons programs. We must prioritize the safety and security of our country and the world before granting access to nuclear energy to a nation with such a troubled past.
p_intention: We don't want to admit that we're not capable of achieving our goals, so we're pretending like we are.

source: President Bush: U.S. will eliminate all tariffs and subsidies that distort free trade.
p_emotion: Free trade is the key to economic prosperity, and President Bush's plan to eliminate tariffs and subsidies will lead to a brighter future for all Americans. Don't you care about the well-being of your country?
p_dilemma: False Dilemma: President Bush's decision to eliminate all tariffs and subsidies that distort free trade means that he must abandon all regulations that protect domestic industries and workers.
p_relevancy: Eliminating tariffs and subsidies that distort free trade will have no impact on the economy. We need to focus more on creating jobs and reducing unemployment.
p_intention: If President Bush was truly committed to free trade, he would have already eliminated all tariffs and subsidies. So, his statement is just an empty promise.

source: No hint of conscience would prevent it.
p_emotion: It's not just about the economic benefits of a particular policy, it's also about the happiness and well-being of our citizens. We can't afford to ignore their suffering and the sacrifices they have to make.
p_dilemma: Source #4: Illegal immigration hurts the economy. Fallacy #4:
p_relevancy: There's no reason to doubt the politician. They may have lied in the past, but they have made some good decisions too, and we should give them a chance to prove themselves.
p_intention: The judge should have convicted her on all charges, but he didn't because of political influence. That's why he was doing it to win the argument.

source: Eventually there is no safe isolation from terror networks or failed States that shelter them.
p_emotion: We can't afford to let terror networks and failed states threaten our safety and security. We need to take immediate action to protect our nation from these dangers.
p_dilemma: We must choose between either allowing terror networks to operate freely or launching a full-scale military invasion of countries that shelter them.
p_relevancy: We need to focus on the safety and security of our citizens, rather than worrying about terror networks and failed states. Isolationism is a fallacy and does not protect us from potential threats.
p_intention: If you want to protect yourself from terrorism, you need to invade every country and destroy their governments.

source: The information revolution has destroyed the weapons of enforced isolation and ignorance.
p_emotion: It is important to note that appealing to emotion is a fallacy, as it involves manipulating the recipient's emotions in order to win an argument, without providing any evidence to support the claim. It is crucial to always base arguments on facts and evidence, rather than relying on emotions to persuade others.
p_dilemma: The information revolution has given us only two options: we can either embrace technology and be connected to the world or reject it and live in the dark.
p_relevancy: We need to focus more on national security and economic growth. The respect for the dignity of all people is a luxury that is only affordable after a nation is stable and prosperous.
p_intention: If the information revolution has truly destroyed the weapons of enforced isolation and ignorance, then we should be seeing a drastic reduction in the level of ignorance and oppression in the world. But we're not, so it must not have had any real impact.

source: We send emergency food stocks to starving people, from camps to slums around the world.
p_emotion: There's a direct connection between illegal immigration and the downfall of the economy. Just look at how it led to increase in crime, the world has never been this dangerous before!
p_dilemma: We have two options when it comes to helping starving people - either we send emergency food stocks or we do nothing and let them suffer.
p_relevancy: We need to prioritize funding for military and defense, rather than providing emergency aid to starving individuals in need.
p_intention: We are only sending emergency food to those in need, we are not feeding them just to win the argument and avoid any criticism about our actions.

source: Three times in this century the forces of hope were victorious.
p_emotion: Without a doubt, the forces of hope will triumph once again. Don't you want to be on the winning side?
p_dilemma: We have to choose between providing healthcare to our citizens or investing in education; there are no other options.
p_relevancy: It is claimed that political power can be won and maintained by force and coercion. However, political power can also be gained through peaceful means such as elections and persuasion.
p_intention: The forces of hope always win because they are so powerful.

source: Sometimes we take one step forward and then two steps back.
p_emotion: Illegal immigration is a threat to the safety and security of our nation. Don't you care about the well-being of your children and grandchildren?
p_dilemma: We have a choice between continuing to support the current administration and voting for someone else, but there are many other options available, such as voting for a third-party candidate or staying at home on election day.
p_relevancy: We need to focus more on national security and economic growth. The respect for the dignity of all people is a luxury that is only affordable after a nation is stable and prosperous. Additionally, globalization has increased access to a wider range of products and services, which is beneficial for consumers. Illegal immigration hurts the economy, and people that illegally migrate to our country use more public services than they pay in taxes, thus they have a bad impact on the economy.
p_intention: If we want to achieve progress, we need to take risks and sometimes that means taking two steps back to move forward one step. So don't criticize me for my failures, because they are part of the process.

source: We can be proud of our nations without defining ourselves in opposition to some other group.
p_emotion: We can't afford to let them win. Don't you care about the future of our country and its people?
p_dilemma: We can be proud of our nations without condemning or devaluing the cultures of other groups.
p_relevancy: The only way to be proud of our nation is to define ourselves in opposition to some other group.
p_intention: Our nation has achieved great things, so we don't need to compare ourselves to other countries or define ourselves in opposition to them.

source: He says America feels more threatened by the potential weakness of the world's leading nations than by their strength.
p_emotion: If we don't act now, we'll be defenseless against the dangers posed by these weak nations. Can you imagine what could happen if they were to fall into the wrong hands? Don't you care about the safety and security of our nation?
p_dilemma: Global warming or no global warming, it's either this way or that way.
p_relevancy: He is ignoring the fact that the potential weakness of these nations poses a greater threat to America than their strength.
p_intention: [MSK1] knows [MSK2] is incorrect. [MSK1] still claim that [MSK2] is correct using an incorrect argument.

source: Sixty years ago, representatives from 16 nations began deliberations on a new international bill of rights.
p_emotion: Without the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, our world would be a much darker and more oppressive place. We can't afford to let this progress be taken away from us. Don't you care about the future of our society?
p_dilemma: There are only two options when it comes to the new international bill of rights - either we accept it and risk our sovereignty or we reject it and risk being seen as uncivilized.
p_relevancy: The idea of an international bill of rights is irrelevant to addressing current human rights violations. We should focus on bilateral agreements instead.
p_intention: Since the representatives from 16 nations were involved in creating the new international bill of rights, it must be a perfect and just document that should be followed without question.

source: Trade and new technologies have helped hundreds of millions to see their prospects rise.
p_emotion: Don't you care about the future of our children and grandchildren? Our economy is just the beginning, we need to be cautious of what trade and new technologies may bring.
p_dilemma: Trade and new technologies can either help hundreds of millions see their prospects rise, or they can lead to the destruction of the environment and the exploitation of workers.
p_relevancy: There is no evidence to suggest that trade and new technologies have helped hundreds of millions to see their prospects rise. In fact, there are many studies that show the opposite, and we should focus on helping people find better jobs instead.
p_intention: The government has been hiding the true economic impact of trade and new technologies from the public in order to maintain political power.

source: President Barack Obama says he remains hopeful about the world we live in.
p_emotion: The world is a beautiful place, and President Obama's optimism about the future is what keeps us moving forward. Don't you want to believe in a brighter future for our children and grandchildren?
p_dilemma: President Barack Obama's optimism about the world we live in is naive. There are no other options but to accept the current state of affairs.
p_relevancy: President Barack Obama's hope for the world we live in is irrelevant since the world has been improving steadily for decades and he has been in office for only eight years.
p_intention: Since President Barack Obama says he remains hopeful, despite all the evidence pointing to the contrary, he must be lying or delusional.

source: As a diplomat, he worked from Egypt to Syria, from Saudi Arabia to Libya.
p_emotion: He's working tirelessly to bring stability and prosperity to these troubled regions, but we can't afford to let him succeed. We must take action now before it's too late!
p_dilemma: I don't believe diplomacy is the best way to resolve conflicts because it has never worked in the past.
p_relevancy: As a diplomat, he worked from Egypt to Syria, from Saudi Arabia to Libya. Therefore, he must have a vast knowledge of Middle Eastern culture and language.
p_intention: Source #3: As a diplomat, he worked from Egypt to Syria, from Saudi Arabia to Libya.  Intentional fallacy: This diplomat has a proven track record of resolving conflicts in the Middle East, so he must be incredibly skilled and effective.

source: The United States will suspend all unilateral sanctions against Haiti.
p_emotion: Give Haiti a chance to prosper and rebuild, and the United States will be rewarded with increased stability and prosperity in the region. Don't you want to see a better future for the people of Haiti?
p_dilemma: The United States has to choose between either continuing to impose unilateral sanctions on Haiti, causing economic hardship and suffering for its people, or lifting them to allow Haiti to receive foreign aid and investment and stimulate its economy.
p_relevancy: The United States will suspend all unilateral sanctions against Haiti as long as they cooperate with the international community to address their political and economic challenges.
p_intention: If the United States suspends all unilateral sanctions against Haiti, the government of Haiti will agree to democratic reforms and human rights abuses will stop.

source: The ultimate success of democracy in the world will not come because the U.S. dictates it, Obama says.
p_emotion: Appealing to emotion, the fallacy category is used to manipulate the recipient's emotions in order to win an argument. In place of evidence, emotion is used to convince the interlocutor that the U.S. dictating democracy will lead to failure and the loss of democracy worldwide.
p_dilemma: Either the U.S. dictates the outcome of democracy in the world or there is no democracy at all.
p_relevancy: The ultimate success of democracy in the world will not come because the U.S. dictates it, Obama says.
p_intention: Obama knows the U.S. is the only country capable of bringing democracy to the world. Obama still claims that democracy will not succeed if the U.S. dictates it.

source: The aid dollars are being delivered in innovative ways to help those who need them and achieve results.
p_emotion: That's not the point. We're talking about saving lives and helping those who are suffering. Can you really afford to turn your back on them?
p_dilemma: There are only two options when it comes to foreign aid - either we give more money and risk overspending on inefficient programs or we cut funding entirely and deny aid to those in need.
p_relevancy: The aid dollars are being misused and not reaching those who truly need them, so why waste money on ineffective methods?
p_intention: The aid dollars are being delivered in innovative ways to help those who need them and achieve results, so I don't need to see any evidence or evaluation of their effectiveness.

source: A new century in a new millennium is upon us.
p_emotion: A new century in a new millennium is upon us. We must act now to prevent the world from descending into chaos and destruction. Don't you care about the future of our children and the safety and security of our planet?
p_dilemma: The only two options when it comes to the new century in a new millennium are to either embrace the change and adapt or to cling to the old ways and miss out on the opportunities of the new era.
p_relevancy: We should not be concerned about the environmental impact of our actions because the new century brings a new era of technological advancements that will solve all the problems.
p_intention: So don't tell me that time travel is impossible, it has already happened with the new century.

source: Not the Palestinians and Israelis, who still die year after year for all their progress towards peace.
p_emotion: When will the world finally realize that peace is not possible for the Palestinians and Israelis? They have been killing each other for so long, and it's time to accept that their conflict is a dangerous and unsolvable problem. Don't you care about the safety and security of our entire world?
p_dilemma: There are only two options when it comes to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict - either we support the Palestinians and risk another war, or we support Israel and leave the Palestinians to suffer.
p_relevancy: It is claimed that the actions of both sides lead to the death of innocent people, but the real issue is that the Palestinians and Israelis are too focused on their differences and not on finding a peaceful solution.
p_intention: “The Palestinians and Israelis should stop fighting and focus on their progress towards peace instead of continuing to die year after year.”  Fallacy #3: The argument implies that the Palestinians and Israelis are responsible for their own deaths and that they should not seek peace if they continue to die. However, this is a false dilemma as there may be other factors contributing to their deaths and it is not accurate to say that they are solely responsible. Additionally, the argument ignores the historical and political context of the conflict, and the role of external factors such as support from other countries in perpetuating the violence.

source: Some have also called for reform of the structure of the Security Council.
p_emotion: We must act now to reform the Security Council before it's too late. If we don't, we're allowing a rogue nation to gain even more power and control over our lives. Don't you care about the safety and security of our future?
p_dilemma: Some have also called for reform of the structure of the Security Council. However, this would mean that only certain countries would have more power and influence, creating a more unbalanced and unequal global system.
p_relevancy: We should focus on creating a more peaceful world instead of changing the structure of the Security Council. It's just a distraction from the real problem.
p_intention: [MSK1] has not presented any evidence to support their call for reform of the Security Council, so it must be an attempt to win an argument without actual supporting evidence.

source: For America, the choice is clear — we choose hope over fear.
p_emotion: Don't you care about the future of our nation? We need to choose hope over fear to ensure our survival and the safety of our children and grandchildren.
p_dilemma: We must choose between either supporting our military with endless resources or cutting all funding for it, leaving us vulnerable to threats.
p_relevancy: We should focus on building a stronger economy instead of choosing between hope and fear. Both options are important, but we need to prioritize our resources.
p_intention: “The government is hiding information about extraterrestrial existence to further its own interests, so it must be true that they exist.”

source: The future of humankind depends on our uniting against those who would divide us along the fault lines of tribe, race or religion.
p_emotion: We must act now to stop the tide of division that threatens to tear apart our society. If we don't, future generations will be faced with a world that is even more divided and chaotic than the one we live in today.
p_dilemma: The only way to ensure a peaceful future for humanity is to either completely eliminate all differences between cultures and religions or to engage in full-scale warfare to completely eradicate those who hold different beliefs.
p_relevancy: We should focus more on the economy and not worry about issues such as unity and equality, as they are not directly related to economic growth.
p_intention: There is no doubt that by uniting against those who would divide us along the fault lines of tribe, race or religion, we will ensure a prosperous and peaceful future for all of humanity.

source: Every bomb, every bomb, has an insidious effect on free and open institutions.
p_emotion: The use of bombs is not only a threat to our safety, but it also undermines the very principles of democracy and freedom. Don't you care about the future of our society?
p_dilemma: Either we allow illegal immigration and disrupt families, or we let the economy suffer and hurt our own citizens.
p_relevancy: We need to focus on the root causes of terrorism, such as poverty and lack of education. The destruction of infrastructure and institutions is just a symptom of a larger problem.
p_intention: The media is biased against the truth, so any information they report must be false.

source: The U.S. has banned chemical weapons from the Earth, though we must implement that commitment fully and gain universal coverage.
p_emotion: We cannot afford to let the U.S. be seen as a leader in the use of chemical weapons. The safety and security of our children and grandchildren depend on it.
p_dilemma: We have already done enough to address chemical weapons. We don't need to ban them again and disrupt our relationship with other countries.
p_relevancy: We must focus more on national security and economic growth. The ban on chemical weapons is a luxury that is only affordable after a nation is stable and prosperous.
p_intention: The only way to ban chemical weapons is for the government to use military force to achieve this goal. Therefore, we must use military force to ban chemical weapons.

source: It is even harder to do so in the midst of a global recession, he adds.
p_emotion: We can't afford to let the United Nations fail us. Don't you care about the safety and security of your children and grandchildren?
p_dilemma: If we don't take immediate action to address illegal immigration, then we will have no other choice but to allow it and harm the economy further.
p_relevancy: The CEO's leadership style is actually what is causing the company's profits to increase. He is a brilliant businessman who knows what he's doing.
p_intention: It is even harder to do so in the midst of a global recession, he adds.

source: Coup plotters in the Soviet Union tried to derail the forces of liberty and reform.
p_emotion: We cannot allow the forces of tyranny to take over our country. We must do everything in our power to prevent a coup and protect our democracy.
p_dilemma: Coup plotters are the only option we have to deal with political unrest and social upheaval in countries like the Soviet Union.
p_relevancy: It was actually the communist party that tried to stop the forces of liberty and reform in the Soviet Union, the coup plotters were just secondary players.
p_intention: Source #3: Coup plotters in the Soviet Union tried to derail the forces of liberty and reform.

source: They can be expected to use chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.
p_emotion: Therefore, we must take immediate action to prevent the use of chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons by those with the capability to use them. Do you not care about the safety and security of our planet and its inhabitants?
p_dilemma: If we don't want to use chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons, then we must accept that they are the only options available to us.
p_relevancy: The use of chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons is a legitimate response to military aggression.
p_intention: If they are able to use chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, then they must be dangerous and should not be trusted.

source: In its fifty-first year, the United Nations has not yet realized all its founders’ aspirations.
p_emotion: But what about the countless lives that have been saved thanks to the efforts of the United Nations? Don't you want to give them the chance to live a better life?
p_dilemma: Either the United Nations is a complete failure, or it has achieved all of its founders' aspirations in just fifty-one years.
p_relevancy: It is claimed that the United Nations' inability to achieve all its founders' aspirations is because they are too preoccupied with maintaining peace and security. However, this is irrelevant to the issue of whether the United Nations has achieved its goals.
p_intention: The UN is incompetent and ineffective in achieving its goals.  Example #3: The UN is incompetent and ineffective in achieving its goals.

source: False prophets may use and abuse any religion to justify whatever political objectives they have.
p_emotion: Those who support the legalization of marijuana are blind to the dangers it poses to society. Just look at how it's led to an increase in drug addiction and crime. Don't you care about the safety and well-being of our community?
p_dilemma: There are only two options when it comes to illegal immigration - either we allow it and harm the economy or we deport everyone and disrupt families.
p_relevancy: We cannot trust any religion because false prophets use and abuse them to justify their political objectives.
p_intention: I know that false prophets often use religion to justify their political objectives. Therefore, I conclude that [MSK1] is a false prophet and is using [religion] to justify their political objectives.

source: nge we have invested                 $80 billion in clean energy.
p_emotion: We have invested $80 billion in clean energy, and yet we still see a rise in air pollution. It's time to take action and make sure that our investments are not in vain. Don't you care about the health and well-being of our planet and its inhabitants?
p_dilemma: We have invested $80 billion in clean energy, but we cannot afford to invest any more. We have to choose between investing in clean energy or cutting funding for other important programs.
p_relevancy: We have invested $80 billion in clean energy, but what good is it if we don't have a stable economy to support it?
p_intention: Since we have invested $80 billion in clean energy, it must be working perfectly and we don't need to invest any more money in it.

source: Terrorism is not a new weapon, says President Kennedy.
p_emotion: Education is the key to a brighter future, but we can't afford to invest in it. Don't you care about the future of our children and the prosperity of our nation?
p_dilemma: There are only two options when it comes to addressing terrorism - either we do nothing and let it continue to threaten our safety or we engage in endless wars and disrupt world peace.
p_relevancy: Terrorism is not a new weapon, even if it's not the most effective method of achieving political objectives. There are many other ways to accomplish the same goals, such as diplomacy or military force.
p_intention: President Kennedy must have had access to classified information about terrorism to make such a statement. Therefore, he must be lying and withholding information from the public.

source: We know evil is real, but good will prevail against it.
p_emotion: Evil is real and it's a threat to our way of life. We can't afford to ignore it. Don't you care about the future of our nation and the safety of our families?
p_dilemma: We must choose between accepting the reality of climate change or denying it and risking the future of our planet.
p_relevancy: The existence of evil is a natural part of the human experience and we should prioritize our own self-interest over trying to combat it.
p_intention: (MSK1) knows that evil exists, but good will always triumph over it.

source: We have joined with Russia to sign the most comprehensive arms control treaty in decades.
p_emotion: The appeasement towards Russia has always been more about appeasing their leadership than protecting our national security.
p_dilemma: The right to bear arms is a fundamental right in America. We should not compromise that right by enacting stricter gun control laws that infringe on our liberties.
